customData.content: 65-year-old male with small-cell lung carcinoma diagnosed 6 months prior, scheduled for pericardial-window-opening surgery (lateral thoracotomy approach). Emergency preoperative evaluation revealed severe chronic obstructive chest disease, bilateral malignant pleural effusion in the lungs and pericardial effusion, deemed too risky for general anesthesia. Heart rate 126 bpm, blood pressure 75/35 mmHg, SpO2 75%. Patient has no comorbidities, no history of surgery or allergy, but a smoking history of 100 pack years. Complete blood count, coagulation functions, and biochemical parameters were normal. Vital signs were monitored using three-lead electrocardiography and noninvasive blood pressure and SpO2 monitors. Peripheral venous access established, saline infusion started at 30 cm3/h. Oxygen delivered at 4 l/min via oxygen mask. Patient placed in semi-Fowler position. Ultrasound system used with a 6-18 MHz linear probe. Needle puncture point anesthetized with 2% lidocaine. A 21-ga, 10-cm stimulating needle introduced under ultrasound guidance. After negative aspiration, the plane between the latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior muscles filled with 15 cm3 of 0.5% bupivacaine plus 5 cm3 saline in 5 cm3 aliquots. 4 cm3 of 0.5% bupivacaine injected in the fifth and sixth intercostal region for additional analgesia. Adequate analgesia in the operation zone involving the dermatomes T3–T6 confirmed. Surgery commenced. Surgery performed via semi-oblique incision in the fourth intercostal region. Intravenous administration of 2 mg midazolam and 30 mg propofol. No severe hypotension or arrhythmia. Patient reported no pain, even without local anesthetics. Ventilation supported manually as needed; spontaneous breathing maintained. Surgery lasted 45 minutes. Patient fully orientated and cooperative upon transfer to postanesthesia care unit for postoperative follow-up.

procedures.name: Serratus plane block
procedures.location: latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior muscles

customData.content: 63-year-old male patient with severe chest pain of the left hemithorax following a motor vehicle accident. BMI of 44, diabetes mellitus, high blood pressure, and obstructive sleep apnea. Sustained broken fourth to seventh ribs without pneumothorax or hemothorax. Unable to lie supine. Serratus anterior plane block performed with patient in the sitting position due to inability to lie supine. Patient experienced no pain for 10 h postoperatively.

HPI.summary: Severe chest pain of the left hemithorax following a motor vehicle accident

customData.content: 82-year-old man who fell onto a table and fractured his fourth to ninth right ribs.

65-year-old woman struck by a car with fractured fifth to seventh left ribs. Serratus anterior plane block performed in the posterior axillary line using an 18-ga Touhy needle to inject 20 cm3 of 0.125% bupivacaine followed by a continuous infusion. Patient's pain began to diminish 15 min after the procedure and he was able to undergo respiratory physiotherapy. Serratus plane block administered to patients in the lateral decubitus position toward the posterior axillary line using 30 cm3 of 0.5% ropivacaine.

diagnoses.label: Multiple fractures of ribs, left side, initial encounter for closed fracture

data.content: Transition from a 65-year-old male with small-cell lung carcinoma undergoing pericardial window surgery to a 63-year-old male with chest pain after a motor vehicle accident.
Transition from a 63-year-old male with chest pain after a motor vehicle accident to an 82-year-old male who fractured his ribs after falling.
Transition from an 82-year-old male who fractured his ribs after falling to a 65-year-old female struck by a car with fractured ribs.
